material.mattext: We know that the "upper tail probability" of 3 under the Z distribution, P(Z>3), is roughly .0015 (using the 99.7% part of the SD rule for the normal distributions). Which of the following do you think is the upper tail probability of 3 under the t distribution in the figure above?

Incorrect. Note that the t-distribution is more spread out than the z-distribution and, therefore, values that are further away from the mean (0) are more likely. In particular, under the t-distribution it is more likely to get values that are above 3 than under the Z-distribution. Visually, you can see that the t-distribution has heavier tails and, therefore, the area under the t-distribution to the right of 3 is larger than the area to the right of 3 under the Z distribution.

Good Job! Indeed, the t-distribution is more spread out than the Z-distribution and, therefore, values that are further away from the mean (0) are more likely. In particular, under the t-distribution it is more likely to get values that are above 3 than under the Z-distribution. Visually, you can see that the t-distribution has heavier tails and, therefore, the area under the t-distribution to the right of 3 is larger than the area to the right of 3 under the z distribution.

Incorrect. Note that the t-distribution is more spread out than the Z-distribution and, therefore, values that are further away from the mean (0) are more likely. In particular, under the t-distribution it is more likely to get values that are above 3 than under the Z-distribution. Visually, you can see that the t-distribution has heavier tails and, therefore, the area under the t-distribution to the right of 3 is larger than the area to the right of 3 under the Z distribution.
